reasoning: The critique targets one sub-argument in Section 3.3: that (difference-making) bounded views with separate aggregation of goods/bads become extremely fussy because even tiny fractions of bads prevent a mostly-great future. This is relevant but not load-bearing for the whole ‘no easy eutopia’ conclusion, which also rests on other routes to fussiness (e.g., linear/unbounded views, practical linearity of many bounded views, and the broader “fragility/product of factors” story), so centrality is moderate (~0.3). The critique’s refutation power is low because it mainly asserts that many moral theories are context-sensitive and not well-modeled by separable aggregation, without showing that the paper’s separate-aggregation modeling is unjustified for the class of views it claims is “most plausible,” or that context-sensitivity would actually remove the extreme sensitivity-to-bads result. It also labels this as a “reference class failure,” which is not clearly the right diagnosis. Still, it is directionally correct that many moral theories don’t fit simple additive/separable structures and that this could weaken a claim of necessity (‘bounded views must be fussy in this way’). The critique is fairly clear and focused, with little extraneous material. Overall it poses only a small problem for the position.
title: Context-dependent moral tradeoffs challenge the separability assumption behind bounded fussiness
